Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S5J-BV31-DXKP-J10J-00000-00A safety belt for the Internet2018-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:38ZLexisNexisA safety belt for the InternetAndrew Keen

Andrew Keen is executive director of the Silicon Valley innovation salon Futurecast. His latest book is "How To Fix The Future."

SANTA ROSA, Calif. - In 1965, Ralph Nader published "Unsafe At Any Speed," his bestselling exposé about the mortal dangers of cars without seat belts. Poorly designed cars had, Nader showed, increased the deaths on American roads by 38 percent between 1961 and 1965. The economics of what he called "highway carnage" were equally appalling, costing America more than $66 billion in today's dollars in property damage, lost wages, and medical and insurance expenses.

Today, of course, all cars come with safety belts. That's because in the half-century since Nader's book, the car industry has, indeed, been held accountable for its products. But now there is a need for a new kind of safety belt. The contemporary equivalent of the out-of-control American auto industry of the past is today's equally out-of-control big tech industry.

Products from tech giants are exploiting our democracy with "post-truth" lies. The digital revolution has become so all-consuming as to potentially kill our ability to consume anything except bite-sized nuggets of information. Researchers are discovering that social media is making our kids less happy. And the apps and platforms that now consume our lives are addictive, as New York University psychologist Adam Alter has detailed.

"In the 1960s, we swam through waters with only a few hooks: cigarettes, alcohol and drugs that were expensive and generally inaccessible," Alter argues. "In the 2010s, those same waters are littered with hooks. There's the Facebook hook. The Instagram hook. The porn hook. The email hook. The online shipping hook. The list is long - far longer than it's ever been in human history, and we're only just learning the power of these hooks."

So, who is to provide us with defenses against these "hooks?" The history of the seat belt is instructive here. Nader's findings in his book elicited a collective gasp from society. The result was action, through a mix of government regulation, design innovation, consumer activism, citizen engagement and improved education that triggered increasingly safe vehicles. That mix is needed now - a combined approach from all of us.

Nothing will happen without creative regulation. European regulators like E.U. Commissioner of Competition Margrethe Vestager, who is aggressively examining the antitrust case against Google, have already emitted a collective gasp about the detrimental effects of the digital revolution on society. They should be our model here.

In May, the E.U. plans to introduce an ambitious new data privacy law, the General Data Privacy Regulation (GDPR), which attempts to empower consumers against private big data corporations. Individual European governments have woken up to the threat - Germany, for example, passed a law that levies significant fines on digital media platforms that allow the publication of illegal content.

American lawmakers need to take note. The Federal Trade Commission needs to look much more critically at the antitrust issue, particularly in terms of Google's dominance of the informational economy and Amazon's stranglehold on e-commerce. Congress needs to work on its own data protection law, which should learn from and improve on the European GDPR.

Most importantly, American politicians need to level the regulatory playing field so that the private superpowers of Silicon Valley are treated like accountable media companies under the law. They need to look critically at the notorious Safe Harbor provision of the 1998 Digital Millennium Copyright Act, which enables Internet companies to escape accountability for the illegal content published on their platforms.

Good regulation always stimulates innovation. The introduction of the GDPR in Europe is already triggering a new wave of digital start-ups that take advantage of this new law to provide consumers with services that protect their data privacy instead of exploiting it. The same explosion of entrepreneurial innovation will accompany effective antitrust regulation that enables start-ups to take on dominant powers.

The U.S. government antitrust investigation of Microsoft in the late 1990s triggered the Web 2.0 revolution of the early 2000s. But today, we are back in the anti-competitive environment of an economy dominated by a tiny handful of winner-take-all companies.

But while some of the costs of digital seatbelts need to be incorporated by Silicon Valley, we also need to pay for genuinely consumer-friendly products. Just as we use cash to buy food, rent or transportation, we should also be paying cash for our online search or social networking.  Online accountability is a two-way street. If we want our online data to be genuinely protected, we have to pay for that privilege.

Ultimately, we are all personally accountable for wearing our new seat belts that will protect us from monopolistic companies and exploitative technologies. Adam Alter's "hooks" can only be confronted by each of us individually. No new law or product will completely protect us.

Just as with tobacco, fast food or gambling, it's our job as responsible adults with free will to make sure that we are buckled up for the digital journey. This requires self-discipline and personal accountability. It means that we each have to personally confront and master our digital demons. Most importantly, it means that we have to pass on self-regulatory wisdom to our kids and students.

However, just as car seat belts were eventually developed in Detroit, our digital seat belts are going to need to be designed in Silicon Valley. The good news is that this is already beginning to happen. Tristan Harris, a former design ethicist at Google, who has been described as "the closest thing Silicon Valley has to a conscience," has gone as far as to argue that software developers should sign a code of conduct, a kind of digital Hippocratic oath, promising to design products that respect their users. Harris believes there needs to be new design and certification standards to ensure against addictive products.

Some things never change. In 1965, Ralph Nader observed that: "A great problem of contemporary life is how to control the power of economic interests that ignore the harmful effects of their applied science and technology." Fifty years on, we must tackle that problem again, this time to deliver digital seat belts to protect ourselves from the myriad hooks of the Internet age.

This was produced by The WorldPost , a partnership of the Berggruen Institute and The Washington Post.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5J0C-B611-F06X-W48W-00000-00As AIG Shrinks, IT Department Awaits Impact;With the large P&C insurer simultaneously making big tech investments and attempting to shrink its footprint, it's business as usual for IT.2016-01-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:39ZLexisNexisSECURITY & RISKAs AIG Shrinks, IT Department Awaits ImpactWith the large P&C insurer simultaneously making big tech investments and attempting to shrink its footprint, it's business as usual for IT.Danni Santana and Nathan Golia

AIG'sannouncement last week that it would splinter into "modular" business units in order to prepare for potential sales is likely to lead to uncertaintly across the organization, but the immediate impact on IT is unlikely to be too great, according to industry experts.

In fact, tech employees could find themselves busier in the short term as AIG figures out how to set up operations with its newly spun-off units, says Robert McIsaac, senior VP of research & consulting at Novarica. AIG is definitively planning to exit the mortgage insurance business, for example.

"The impact on IT largely ultimately depends on AIG's tech strategy," said McIsaac. "AIG is under pressure to cut costs and so too will its businesses. Either everyone gets a haircut or they will invest heavily in tech while cutting funds elsewhere. Meaning, everyone in IT has a job."

The AIG drama reaches back into 2015. In November, the company announced a $500 million restructuring plan thatincluded $100 millionfor "costs associated with modernization of information technology platforms." The company alsomoved around several executives, but tech leadership was left untouched.

"We'll continue to make select investments in technology and innovation to build sustainable competitive advantages," Peter Hancock, AIG CEO, said at the time. "Our strategy focuses on four major objectives: to narrow our focus on businesses where we can grow profitably, drive for efficiency, grow through innovation and optimizing our data assets, and return excess capital."

But at the same time that it was trying to streamline its overall business, AIG made several investments in technology: itpledged $4 million to Clemson Universityfor analytics education, invested ina wearable technology startup, andadded its first CTOlast year.

A request for comment from AIG was not returned by press time.

At issue for AIG and two other insurers -- MetLife and Prudential -- is their designation as structurally important financial institutions, or SIFIs, under regulation established in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis. Investor Carl Icahn, who has been a vocal critic of AIG's management and strategy, has implored the company to get itself below that threshold.

"AIG is in the middle of the too big to fail conversation, which involves both insurers and banks," McIsaac notes. "They are the most recent SIFI organization to announce some sort of divestiture, joining MetLife and GE. But the question is, are they right in doing so? If they are, we will probably see other SIFI companies follow in their footsteps to make themselves less systematically significant."

While assets sold off by AIG are more contained and separate from its P&C commercial lines business, there will be technology implications depending on how dependent they will be on their parent company, Mclssac concludes.

"Are these stand-alone businesses with stand-alone technologies?" he says. "Installation of new tech may be required solely to connect United Guaranty to company shares servers" after the spinoff, he explains.

urn:contentItem:5WGW-5221-DYTY-C19P-00000-00As Amazon hits a milestone, what comes next?;The online retailer has lasted 25 years but must keep on pushing boundaries if it wants to stay at the top of its game, writes Tom Hoggins2019-07-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:38ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 5As Amazon hits a milestone, what comes next?The online retailer has lasted 25 years but must keep on pushing boundaries if it wants to stay at the top of its game, writes Tom HogginsTom Hoggins

By now, the birth of Amazon on July 5 1994 is a wellworn tale. On this day 25 years ago, 30-year old "Wall Street whizz-kid" Jeff Bezos finally packed in his comfortable hedge fund job to set up an online bookstore from a garage in Seattle.

Today, Bezos's brainchild is the second most valuable company in the world, worth $928bn, and is described as "the most powerful brand" on Earth.

Amazon's reach and growth seems limitless. But as Bezos said to his employees recently: "Amazon is not too big to fail. In fact, I predict one day Amazon will fail. If you look at large companies, their lifespans tend to be 30-plus years, not a hundred-plus years."

Bezos may be right. As the company looks to the next step in its seeming bid for world domination, it will still need to face down challenges from both consumer and regulatory headwinds.

Amazon's activities in the retail sector are perhaps the most recognised, and the most criticised. However, in a letter to shareholders in April, Bezos even said that Amazon was still "a small player in global retail".

Retail sales at Amazon have risen from $51bn to $59.7bn in the first quarter of 2019. However, growth has slowed dramatically. In North America, revenues increased 17pc compared to 46pc in 2018, with international growth dropping to 9pc from 34pc.

But there are problems brewing across the pond. A federal court ruling on Thursday that Amazon can be held liable for a dog collar sold on its website that partly blinded a woman could complicate the online merchant's business if it is applied broadly.

More than half the items sold on the popular site come from independent merchants. Amazon takes a commission on sales and charges additional fees for storing products in its warehouses, packaging them and delivering them.

But it technically doesn't own the inventory, a fact it has used to protect itself from product liability cases. Closer to home, a report by consumer group Which? found that unscrupulous sellers are beating Amazon's security systems with tactics such as bribery and hacking to post fake reviews for their products.

The watchdog said features designed to make the online giant's website more user-friendly were being "abused on a grand scale" to mislead customers.

These challenges haven't stopped Bezos from innovating and making aggressive acquisitions such as the $13.7bn purchase of Whole Foods in 2017 - but whether his approach will pay off remains to be seen.

"There are two types of retailers in the world today. Those which will be replaced by Amazon, and those which won't," says Ivan Mazour, chief executive and founder of AI-powered customer marketing platform Ometria.

"Amazon's all-encompassing vision will provide us with all of our 'needs'. But our 'wants' will continue to be satisfied by innovative 'direct to consumer' brands."

While Amazon certainly will have its eyes on the future of retail, its cloud computing platform Amazon Web Services (AWS) is now its most profitable business. Launched in 2002, AWS has quietly established itself as one of the most prominent technology platforms in the world and is on track to earn $31bn in revenue this year.

Essentially selling cloud computing and storage as a service, AWS is used by 5,000 government organisations worldwide, institutions such as NASA and huge companies like Uber and Netflix.

AWS currently commands a 32pc share of the cloud service market, far ahead of closest competitor Microsoft at 16pc. And its revenue grew 41pc for the first three months of 2019.

Although that is a dip from 2018's 49pc increase.

Both Microsoft and Google are placing more emphasis on their cloud services, from video game streaming to connecting machines around the world. But while this new focus will be a threat, Amazon is already entrenched.

"Microsoft is probably the biggest threat to Amazon in the cloud market," says Halliwell. "But across the spread of industries that Amazon operates in, it will take a number of partners or a conglomerate working collaboratively to overthrow their dominance."

Possibly the greatest threat to Amazon in the coming years is antitrust laws, competition commissions and even consumers suffering from "Amazon fatigue" deciding enough is enough.

"How long will we, the public, allow it to grow and extend its monopoly?" asks Halliwell.

"How long will the Competition Commission and Federal Trade Commission allow Amazon to extend its monopoly? "We've recently seen changes in Federal attitude to the big tech firms. I think we'll see this play out very quick in the run-up to the US elections."

Indeed, Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren has called for a break-up of big tech, which could more formally separate AWS from the Amazon mother ship and unwind significant mergers such as the one with Whole Foods.

The company also continues to face scrutiny over work conditions in warehouses and the company's tax contributions.

The US government is gearing up for a major probe into big tech, which could lead to a significant break-up and one that Amazon will be looking to prepare for.

"I think this is highly likely," says Halliwell. "If they're smart they are already thinking about how to do this proactively to prevent regulatory intervention."

Mazour, however, is not so sure. "Out of all the tech giants, Amazon is the one which has the lowest risk of being broken up," he says.

"It has competed fairly at all times, and won through effective execution rather than by blocking others."

Regardless of government intervention, Bezos's observation that even Amazon is at risk in the long term means that the company will need to focus on other growth areas to preserve its momentum.

"I would argue that eCommerce, Cloud and AI are its more mature industries and not its key growth areas," says Halliwell.

"Amazon will also see significant growth in its supply chain and logistics businesses over the next three years."

That has been the key to Amazon's success in the last 25 years. Ever since it began life as a Seattle garage bookstore, it has looked to expand and explore, interlinking its businesses with its deep engineering and technical capability.

This has given in the agility to move into adjacent industries quickly and with success. And it seems unlikely to stop any time soon.

"Jeff Bezos said that he spends most of his time thinking a minimum of three years out. That's likely an understatement," says Mazour. "Amazon has always had a vision way beyond any reality that their customers experience in the now.

"Where it goes next, whether that's drone-based deliveries from floating warehouses, physical stores with no need for tills or shop assistants, or fully-automated smart homes which predict and order what you need without you even asking, we don't know. But I bet Bezos does.

"High though it sounds already, the trillion-dollar valuation that Amazon commands is just the beginning."

With additional reporting by Natasha Dangoor.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WGW-FMC1-JCJY-G4PJ-00000-00As Amazon turns 25, what are the biggest challenges facing the world's most powerful company?2019-07-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:38ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY INTELLIGENCEVersion:1As Amazon turns 25, what are the biggest challenges facing the world's most powerful company?By Tom Hoggins

By now, the inception of Amazon on 5 July 1994 is a well-worn tale. On this day 25 years ago, the 30-year old "Wall Street whizz-kid" Jeff Bezos f inally packed in his comfortable hedge fund job to set up an online bookstore from his garage in Seattle. 

Today, Bezos' brain-child is now the second most valuable company in the world at $928bn, and described as "the most powerful brand" on Earth. 

Amazon's reach and growth seems limitless. But as Bezos said to his employees recently: "Amazon is not too big to fail. In fact, I predict one day Amazon will fail. If you look at large companies, their lifespans tend to be 30-plus years, not a hundred-plus years."

Bezos may be right . As the company looks to the next step in its seeming bid for world domination, it will still need to face down challenges from both consumer and regulatory headwinds. 

Tech company market caps over time

Retail and e-commerce

Amazon's activities in the retail sector are perhaps the most recognised, and the most criticised. In a letter to shareholders in April, Bezos even said that Amazon was still "a small player in global retail."

Retail sales at Amazon have risen from $51 billion to $59.7 billion in the first quarter of 2019. However, growth has slowed dramatically. In North America, revenues increased 17pc compared to 46pc in 2018, with international growth dropping to 9pc from 34pc.

But there are problems brewing across the pond. A federal court ruling on Thursday that Amazon can be held liable for a dog collar sold on its website that partly blinded a woman could complicate the online merchant's business if it is applied broadly. More than half the items sold on the popular site come from independent merchants.

Amazon takes a commission on sales and charges additional fees for storing products in its warehouses, packaging them and delivering them. But it technically doesn't own the inventory, a fact it has used to protect itself from product liability cases. 

Amazon share price

Closer to home, a report by consumer group Which? today found that unscrupulous sellers are beating Amazon's security systems with tactics such as bribery and hacking to post fake reviews for their products. The watchdog said features designed to make the online giant's website more user-friendly were being "abused on a grand scale" to mislead customers.

These challenges haven't stopped Bezos from innovating and making aggressive acquisitions such as the $13.7bn purchase of Whole Foods in 2017 - but whether his approach will pay off remains to be seen. 

"There are two types of retailers in the world today. Those which will be replaced by Amazon, and those which won't," says Ivan Mazour, CEO and founder of AI-powered customer marketing platform Ometria. "Amazon's all-encompassing vision will provide us with all of our 'needs'. But our 'wants' will continue to be satisfied by innovative 'direct to consumer' brands." While Amazon certainly will have its eyes on the future of retail, its cloud computing platform Amazon Web Services (AWS) is now its most profitable business. Launched in 2002, AWS has quietly established itself as one of the most prominent technology platforms in the world and is on track to earn $31bn in revenue this year.

The Cloud and AI

While Amazon certainly will have its eyes on the future of retail, its cloud computing platform Amazon Web Services (AWS) is now its most profitable business. Launched in 2002, AWS has quietly established itself as one of the most prominent technology platforms in the world and is on track to earn $31bn in revenue this year.

Essentially selling cloud computing and storage as a service, AWS is used by 5,000 government organisations worldwide, institutions such as NASA and huge companies like Uber and Netflix.

AWS revenues march ever higher

AWS currently commands a 32pc share of the cloud service market, far ahead of closest competitor Microsoft at 16pc. And its revenue grew 41pc for the first three months of 2019. Although that is a dip from 2018's 49pc increase.

Both Microsoft and Google are placing more emphasis on their cloud services from video game streaming to connecting machines around the world for the Internet of Things (IoT). But while this new focus will be a threat, Amazon is already entrenched.

"Microsoft is probably the biggest threat to Amazon in the cloud market," says Andy Halliwell, UK Retail Lead at digital consultancy Publicis Sapient. "But across the spread of industries that Amazon operates in, it will take a number of partners or a conglomerate working collaboratively to overthrow their dominance."  

AWS also provides artificial intelligence and machine learning tools to organisations such as Formula One and the NFL. The AI industry is yet another growth sector, topping $27bn in investments in 2018, that Amazon already has a foothold in.

As well as machine learning, Amazon has invested in AI for its Alexa-powered voice assistants and robots in its warehouses, with cloud simulations defining routes around fulfilment centres.

Ownership and antitrust

Possibly the greatest threat to Amazon in the coming years is antitrust laws, competition commissions and even consumers suffering from 'Amazon Fatigue' deciding enough is enough.

"How long will we, the public, allow it grow and extend its monopoly?" asks Halliwell. "How long will the Competition Commission and Federal Trade Commission allow Amazon to extend it's monopoly? We've recently seen changes in Federal attitude to the Big Tech firms. I think we'll see this play out very quick in the run up to the US elections."

Indeed, Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren has called for a break-up of big tech, which could more formally separate AWS from the Amazon mothership and unwind significant mergers such as the one with Whole Foods. The company also continues to face scrutiny over work conditions in warehouses and the company's tax contributions.

The US government is gearing up for a major probe into big tech, which could lead to a significant break-up and one that Amazon will be looking to prepare for.

"I think this is highly likely," says Halliwell. "If they're smart they are already thinking about how to do this proactively to prevent regulatory intervention."

Mazour, however, is not so sure. "Out of all the tech giants, Amazon is the one which has the lowest risk of being broken up," he says. "It has competed fairly at all times, and won through effective execution rather than by blocking others."

Keeping the growth going

Regardless of government intervention, Bezos' observation that even Amazon is at risk in the long term means that the company will need to focus on other growth areas to preserve its momentum.

"I would argue that eCommerce, Cloud and AI are its more mature industries and not it's key growth areas," says Halliwell. "Amazon will also see significant growth in its supply chain and logistics businesses over the next 3 years."

That has been the key to Amazon's success in the last 25 years. Ever since it began life as a Seattle garage bookstore, it has looked to expand and explore, interlinking its businesses with its deep engineering and technical capability. This has given in the agility to move into adjacent industries quickly and with success. And it seems unlikely to stop any time soon.

"Jeff Bezos said that he spends most of his time thinking a minimum of three years out. That's likely an understatement," says Mazour. "Amazon has always had a vision way beyond any reality that their customers experience in the now. 

"Where it goes next, whether that's drone-based deliveries from floating warehouses, physical stores with no need for tills or shop assistants, or fully-automated smart homes which predict and order what you need without you even asking, we don't know. But I bet Bezos does. High though it sounds already, the trillion-dollar valuation that Amazon commands is just the beginning."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60MT-V1J1-JB3N-T358-00000-00As Ambani goes on a shopping spree for Jio, startups may find their space shrinking2020-08-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:38ZLexisNexisSTARTUPSAs Ambani goes on a shopping spree for Jio, startups may find their space shrinkingGarima Bora

Last month, tech giants- Amazon, Facebook, Google and Apple in the United States were summoned to testify before Congress to convince the government that they, the four companies collectively worth $4.85 trillion, are not powerful at all. Gigi Sohn, a former senior adviser at the Federal Communications Commission, told the New York Times that this was their Big Tobacco moment, comparing it with the 1994 congressional appearance of the seven largest tobacco company executives, who said they didn't believe cigarettes could be addictive.The allegations against the tech giants range from antitrust, spreading misinformation to unfair competitive practices and leaving no room for small businesses or startups to flourish. In the words of German Economist Klaus Schwab, "In the new world, it is not the big fish which eats the small fish, it's the fast fish which eats the slow fish."Jio Platforms, which over the pandemic made its owner Mukesh Ambani the fourth richest man in the world at one point can, certainly become the biggest and fastest fish in the country. With a plethora of apps and services tapping into every field, Reliance Jio has gradually made itself a digital powerhouse in the last four years. As the branches of Jio Platforms have started covering every nook and corner of the market, many are wondering about the larger implications of a colossal business entity.

No corner untouchedEveryone got more hours on their hands in this pandemic, so did Ambani and he made sure to make a good use of it. The industrialist long ago announced an upcoming e-commerce platform to take over rivals Amazon and Walmart-Flipkart. As the lockdown gave momentum to online grocery and digital payments, JioMart was launched offering the option to order grocery from WhatsApp, courtesy of the million dollar Jio-Facebook deal.Jio Platforms also launched JioMeet in June in order to be a part of the new normal and rising work from home culture and giving competition to Zoom, Google Meet and other video conferencing platforms.With two large players such as Zoom and Jio trying to hog up the majority of the customer attention and market, how much space is left for small startups to run? Homegrown video conferencing startups such as Say Namaste and Videomeet were also launched during the pandemic."Say Namaste beta version that was launched in April was available only as a web version at the time, yet received an immense positive response. Before lockdown say 1 in 100 was communicating through video conferencing and during lockdown, that number touched 100/100," Anuj Garg, CEO, Inscrips, parent company of Say Namaste, told ET Digital.Videomeet, a product of Data Ingenious Global Ltd, was developed after the company participated in the Ministry of Electronics and IT's 'Made in India Video Conferencing Challenge'. According to Ajay Data, CEO, Data Ingenious Global Ltd, Videomeet stands out from other video conferencing platforms, providing low bandwidth catering to villages and areas with low connectivity.Another video conferencing platform offering services for events and webinars is Floor by 10Times, an aggregator of business events. "The pandemic pushed organizers to go virtual and we were able to show them that a lot can be done over virtual events," Atul Todi, founder, 10Times, told ET Digital.When asked about competition from Jio and other startups, Say Namaste's Garg said, "Competition is always good as it gives customers an option to benchmark and make informed decisions. As an entrepreneur, you'd rather be in a hot market than in an empty one."SayNamaste was launched in April and has over 1 million downloads in both Apple Store and Google Play Store together. VideoMeet was launched in late March and has over 100,000 downloads on both platforms. JioMeet was launched in June and within a month witnessed 5 million downloads, as announced by Ambani at RIL's 43rd AGM. Jio Platforms consist of about 18 apps, including JioChat, JioMeet, JioNews, JioGameslite, JioHealthHub, JioCloud, Jio Security, among others.The 'walled' gardenTime and again when confronted with the question of its dominance over rising startups, Jio had flaunted its efforts and assistance towards startups. In the latest RIL AGM, the Reliance Chairman and Managing Director had said, "I believe there is no better partner for Indian startups than Jio." The firm extended support in technology and product development and promised to help startups with market access, distribution and even scale-up capital.Among Jio's acquired startups include Haptik, Embibe, Saavn, EasyGov, all of which have been integrated in Jio's package of services in the last few years. On Tuesday it announced the acquisition of e-pharma startup Netmeds.Jio's initiative towards startups and its acquisition strategy has got a mixed back of reactions from Venture Capital firms. Ankur Bansal, co-founder and Director, BlackSoil believes by investing and acquiring startups Jio has fuelled growth and much needed liquidity in the startup & VC system, especially when VC backed companies have struggled in terms of exits.Similarly, Sanjay Mehta, Founder & Partner 100X.VC says India corporates are finally waking up to the fact that innovation will come from young startups and they are important. "Indian corporations need to start thinking about buy v/s build. It also brings liquidity events for existing angel investors or micro VCs."Anand Lunia, General Partner, India Quotient, advises startups to design their monopoly carefully when partnering with Jio, which has only bought startups so far, but haven't made enough investments."Jio provides access to a large market of Indians using broadband, but is also practically a monopoly. There will be an opportunity for startups to leverage the access to markets and yet they should be careful in designing their dependence on a monopoly. In recent years, dealing with Google, Amazon has been a learning experience for startups world over and in long term startups need to build direct access to their customers. Jio is clear on building its own services, like Amazon, to leverage its platform and hence has only bought startups so far, or built in-house."Presenting more insights of Jio's acquisition strategy towards startups, Anup Jain, Managing Partner, Orios Venture Partners said that startups will need to evaluate the give-take balance. "A typical startup founder would wonder what equity stake does he have to part with, to get to partner with Jio and then, what's the independence he will get to build his startup in terms of choosing a team or further investors. On the other hand, the ability to pilot his proposition with a base of Jio users would be very attractive as a launch pad," he told ET Digital.He added that Jio's acquisitions are only boosting its walled garden of utilities and has given exit to founders who were looking for something like this as an outcome."Jio is certainly building utilities inside its 'walled garden' to retain Jio users for services they may seek on other platforms. It represents an added monetisation opportunity for Jio beyond the traditional data subscription revenue per month, which is obviously not where Jio wishes to stop earning," he said.Silicon Valley trendPankaj Jain, a Silicon Valley investor and Member of Investment Committee of AngelList India, says that while the big tech players are not monopolies, some of them such as Facebook and Google are approaching a disturbing scale. "They touch so much of what we do online, track us and gather so much information about us that it's disturbing. For example, I prefer not to use WhatsApp and limit my use of Facebook and Instagram as much as possible. My primary search engine has not been Google for a number of years now," he said.He pointed out that Google and Facebook make money out of advertising and even though they've had many failed products, free services never fail to attract customers."Google and Facebook make their money on advertising. The more people and the more businesses that use their products, the more money they should make. In turn, if their platforms aren't serving the needs of their users, then users would go to other platforms, e.g. TikTok, Twitter, DuckDuckGo, and Microsoft 365. Google and Facebook have had plenty of failed products that couldn't draw more people in. 'Free', however, is a very compelling offering for most people."When asked if the initiatives offered by big tech companies to support smaller players only have a short term benefit, Jain cited the example of Amazon. "Amazon is a little different and even more nuanced if you separate out their e-commerce and web services businesses. Amazon has a vested interest in more businesses selling via their platform. They have solved a big problem for many small businesses - reaching the end buyer. However, Amazon clearly also takes steps to duplicate the best selling products on the platform, and, creating competition for their own marketplace sellers. The point you make about short-term benefits for some of the people selling on Amazon are true, in some instances."Jio, the next big tech?According to Urvashi Taneja, Founding Director, Tandem Research, a Goa-based research drew similarities of Jio's acquisition strategy with the big tech players trying to gain market dominance through such acquisitions."This is tricky because on one hand many startups are looking to be acquired, but this is likely to be bad for innovation and healthy markets in the long run. Further, with data sharing agreements with these smaller players, Jio can leverage consumer data and grow its market and civic power. Tech giants maintain that they are enabling more consumer choice and would refute the walled garden analogy," she told ET Digital.She adds that Jio will be able to use data intelligence, network efforts, and capital, to crowd out the smaller players in the marketplace. "While it might bring down prices for consumers in the short run, the consolidation of market power is likely to be bad for markets and customers in the longer term," she said.Regulatory minefieldAnupam Sanghi is a lawyer practicing competition and regulatory law. According to her, when such a large player enters the market, small players are put in a tough spot where they have to either collaborate with them or get acquired by them or just get out of the market. She also highlighted other ways of creating market dominance, such as vertical arrangements, citing the example of the CCI probe against MakeMyTrip and Oyo.In February this year, Treebo Hotels filed a complaint against both hospitality chains against MMT closing a vertical arrangement with Oyo, providing franchising services to its budget hotels. Exclusion of Treebo and its partner hotels from MMT listing was seen to have an adverse effect on competition in the market. Further, it was alleged that MMT enforced 'price parity restriction' on Treebo partner hotels restricting them from enlisting properties on Booking.com and Paytm at a better price."This arrangement is called vertical restriction. Here the large players promise no harm to the smaller ones, but that's how they get dominance in the market and solidify the dominance," Sanghi said.Like many industry experts, she also believes that the Jio-Facebook deal opens the possibility of leveraging data to their advantage. The industry experts had called for a CCI investigation in the Jio-Facebook deal as both firms are data giants and collect a lot of data of Indian internet users. They feared this would put them in disadvantage and Jio-Facebook can possibly engage in anti-competitive practices. The CCI, however, cleared the deal."The CCI needs to do a deeper and more sophisticated merger analysis as is being done by developed jurisdictions around the world. Further, for assessing harm or benefit to consumers the CCI needs to know all the relevant markets in which the Super app may create its market (with a combined customer base of FB/ Instagram/ Jio) and where there would be overlaps with existing players. After a cost and benefit analysis they need to consider that privacy concerns need to be addressed (especially since the PDP law is not in force) and commitments need to be mandated for potential dominance issues," Sanghi said. Agreeing with the sentiment, Aneja said that the competition policy needed to be updated to take into consideration control over data and network effects. "Competition policy normally looks at impact on customers in terms of price. But that's not enough in case of zero price/ two-sided marketplace. It needs to also evaluate the impact of controlling customer data, network effects, and effect of M&A on the competitiveness of the market," she said.Jain says regulatory bodies need to take vigil towards privacy and data misuse."I think Privacy is one of the key areas for regulatory bodies to dive into. Establishing clear guardrails around privacy is very important and will only get more important. This is especially important with respect to Google and Facebook. Though Amazon is the dominant e-commerce platform by far (38% market share vs. 6% for #2 Walmart), it is still less than 6% of all US retail sales). That being said, regulatory bodies in the US will eventually have to look at anti-competitive practices because of the massive dominance Amazon has in e-commerce."Comparing Jio with the big tech, Jain said these giants have their hands in everything from streaming to video chat to e-commerce. "They have brand loyalty, a soaring stock price and are intensely competitive, though, perhaps not very innovative with tech products. All big tech companies have shown similar characteristics without controlling the pipes. I think Jio could eventually be the gateway to the Internet in India." For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

urn:contentItem:60MT-V1J1-JB3N-T357-00000-00As Ambani goes on a shopping spree for Jio, startups may find their space shrinking2020-08-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:38ZLexisNexisSTARTUPSAs Ambani goes on a shopping spree for Jio, startups may find their space shrinkingGarima Bora

Last month, tech giants- Amazon, Facebook, Google and Apple in the United States were summoned to testify before Congress to convince the government that they, the four companies collectively worth $4.85 trillion, are not powerful at all. Gigi Sohn, a former senior adviser at the Federal Communications Commission, told the New York Times that this was their Big Tobacco moment, comparing it with the 1994 congressional appearance of the seven largest tobacco company executives, who said they didn't believe cigarettes could be addictive.The allegations against the tech giants range from antitrust, spreading misinformation to unfair competitive practices and leaving no room for small businesses or startups to flourish. In the words of German Economist Klaus Schwab, "In the new world, it is not the big fish which eats the small fish, it's the fast fish which eats the slow fish."Jio Platforms, which over the pandemic made its owner Mukesh Ambani the fourth richest man in the world at one point can, certainly become the biggest and fastest fish in the country. With a plethora of apps and services tapping into every field, Reliance Jio has gradually made itself a digital powerhouse in the last four years. As the branches of Jio Platforms have started covering every nook and corner of the market, many are wondering about the larger implications of a colossal business entity.

No corner untouchedEveryone got more hours on their hands in this pandemic, so did Ambani and he made sure to make a good use of it. The industrialist long ago announced an upcoming e-commerce platform to take over rivals Amazon and Walmart-Flipkart. As the lockdown gave momentum to online grocery and digital payments, JioMart was launched offering the option to order grocery from WhatsApp, courtesy of the million dollar Jio-Facebook deal.Jio Platforms also launched JioMeet in June in order to be a part of the new normal and rising work from home culture and giving competition to Zoom, Google Meet and other video conferencing platforms.With two large players such as Zoom and Jio trying to hog up the majority of the customer attention and market, how much space is left for small startups to run? Homegrown video conferencing startups such as Say Namaste and Videomeet were also launched during the pandemic."Say Namaste beta version that was launched in April was available only as a web version at the time, yet received an immense positive response. Before lockdown say 1 in 100 was communicating through video conferencing and during lockdown, that number touched 100/100," Anuj Garg, CEO, Inscrips, parent company of Say Namaste, told ET Digital.Videomeet, a product of Data Ingenious Global Ltd, was developed after the company participated in the Ministry of Electronics and IT's 'Made in India Video Conferencing Challenge'. According to Ajay Data, CEO, Data Ingenious Global Ltd, Videomeet stands out from other video conferencing platforms, providing low bandwidth catering to villages and areas with low connectivity.Another video conferencing platform offering services for events and webinars is Floor by 10Times, an aggregator of business events. "The pandemic pushed organizers to go virtual and we were able to show them that a lot can be done over virtual events," Atul Todi, founder, 10Times, told ET Digital.When asked about competition from Jio and other startups, Say Namaste's Garg said, "Competition is always good as it gives customers an option to benchmark and make informed decisions. As an entrepreneur, you'd rather be in a hot market than in an empty one."SayNamaste was launched in April and has over 1 million downloads in both Apple Store and Google Play Store together. VideoMeet was launched in late March and has over 100,000 downloads on both platforms. JioMeet was launched in June and within a month witnessed 5 million downloads, as announced by Ambani at RIL's 43rd AGM. Jio Platforms consist of about 18 apps, including JioChat, JioMeet, JioNews, JioGameslite, JioHealthHub, JioCloud, Jio Security, among others.The 'walled' gardenTime and again when confronted with the question of its dominance over rising startups, Jio had flaunted its efforts and assistance towards startups. In the latest RIL AGM, the Reliance Chairman and Managing Director had said, "I believe there is no better partner for Indian startups than Jio." The firm extended support in technology and product development and promised to help startups with market access, distribution and even scale-up capital.Among Jio's acquired startups include Haptik, Embibe, Saavn, EasyGov, all of which have been integrated in Jio's package of services in the last few years. On Tuesday it announced the acquisition of e-pharma startup Netmeds.Jio's initiative towards startups and its acquisition strategy has got a mixed back of reactions from Venture Capital firms. Ankur Bansal, co-founder and Director, BlackSoil believes by investing and acquiring startups Jio has fuelled growth and much needed liquidity in the startup & VC system, especially when VC backed companies have struggled in terms of exits.Similarly, Sanjay Mehta, Founder & Partner 100X.VC says India corporates are finally waking up to the fact that innovation will come from young startups and they are important. "Indian corporations need to start thinking about buy v/s build. It also brings liquidity events for existing angel investors or micro VCs."Anand Lunia, General Partner, India Quotient, advises startups to design their monopoly carefully when partnering with Jio, which has only bought startups so far, but haven't made enough investments."Jio provides access to a large market of Indians using broadband, but is also practically a monopoly. There will be an opportunity for startups to leverage the access to markets and yet they should be careful in designing their dependence on a monopoly. In recent years, dealing with Google, Amazon has been a learning experience for startups world over and in long term startups need to build direct access to their customers. Jio is clear on building its own services, like Amazon, to leverage its platform and hence has only bought startups so far, or built in-house."Presenting more insights of Jio's acquisition strategy towards startups, Anup Jain, Managing Partner, Orios Venture Partners said that startups will need to evaluate the give-take balance. "A typical startup founder would wonder what equity stake does he have to part with, to get to partner with Jio and then, what's the independence he will get to build his startup in terms of choosing a team or further investors. On the other hand, the ability to pilot his proposition with a base of Jio users would be very attractive as a launch pad," he told ET Digital.He added that Jio's acquisitions are only boosting its walled garden of utilities and has given exit to founders who were looking for something like this as an outcome."Jio is certainly building utilities inside its 'walled garden' to retain Jio users for services they may seek on other platforms. It represents an added monetisation opportunity for Jio beyond the traditional data subscription revenue per month, which is obviously not where Jio wishes to stop earning," he said.Silicon Valley trend:Pankaj Jain, a Silicon Valley investor and Member of Investment Committee of AngelList India, says that while the big tech players are not monopolies, some of them such as Facebook and Google are approaching a disturbing scale. "They touch so much of what we do online, track us and gather so much information about us that it's disturbing. For example, I prefer not to use WhatsApp and limit my use of Facebook and Instagram as much as possible. My primary search engine has not been Google for a number of years now," he said.He pointed out that Google and Facebook make money out of advertising and even though they've had many failed products, free services never fail to attract customers."Google and Facebook make their money on advertising. The more people and the more businesses that use their products, the more money they should make. In turn, if their platforms aren't serving the needs of their users, then users would go to other platforms, e.g. TikTok, Twitter, DuckDuckGo, and Microsoft 365. Google and Facebook have had plenty of failed products that couldn't draw more people in. 'Free', however, is a very compelling offering for most people."When asked if the initiatives offered by big tech companies to support smaller players only have a short term benefit, Jain cited the example of Amazon. "Amazon is a little different and even more nuanced if you separate out their e-commerce and web services businesses. Amazon has a vested interest in more businesses selling via their platform. They have solved a big problem for many small businesses - reaching the end buyer. However, Amazon clearly also takes steps to duplicate the best selling products on the platform, and, creating competition for their own marketplace sellers. The point you make about short-term benefits for some of the people selling on Amazon are true, in some instances."Jio, the next big tech?According to Urvashi Taneja, Founding Director, Tandem Research, a Goa-based research drew similarities of Jio's acquisition strategy with the big tech players trying to gain market dominance through such acquisitions."This is tricky because on one hand many startups are looking to be acquired, but this is likely to be bad for innovation and healthy markets in the long run. Further, with data sharing agreements with these smaller players, Jio can leverage consumer data and grow its market and civic power. Tech giants maintain that they are enabling more consumer choice and would refute the walled garden analogy," she told ET Digital.She adds that Jio will be able to use data intelligence, network efforts, and capital, to crowd out the smaller players in the marketplace. "While it might bring down prices for consumers in the short run, the consolidation of market power is likely to be bad for markets and customers in the longer term," she said.Regulatory minefield:Anupam Sanghi is a lawyer practicing competition and regulatory law. According to her, when such a large player enters the market, small players are put in a tough spot where they have to either collaborate with them or get acquired by them or just get out of the market. She also highlighted other ways of creating market dominance, such as vertical arrangements, citing the example of the CCI probe against MakeMyTrip and Oyo.In February this year, Treebo Hotels filed a complaint against both hospitality chains against MMT closing a vertical arrangement with Oyo, providing franchising services to its budget hotels. Exclusion of Treebo and its partner hotels from MMT listing was seen to have an adverse effect on competition in the market. Further, it was alleged that MMT enforced 'price parity restriction' on Treebo partner hotels restricting them from enlisting properties on Booking.com and Paytm at a better price."This arrangement is called vertical restriction. Here the large players promise no harm to the smaller ones, but that's how they get dominance in the market and solidify the dominance," Sanghi said.Like many industry experts, she also believes that the Jio-Facebook deal opens the possibility of leveraging data to their advantage. The industry experts had called for a CCI investigation in the Jio-Facebook deal as both firms are data giants and collect a lot of data of Indian internet users. They feared this would put them in disadvantage and Jio-Facebook can possibly engage in anti-competitive practices. The CCI, however, cleared the deal."The CCI needs to do a deeper and more sophisticated merger analysis as is being done by developed jurisdictions around the world. Further, for assessing harm or benefit to consumers the CCI needs to know all the relevant markets in which the Super app may create its market (with a combined customer base of FB/ Instagram/ Jio) and where there would be overlaps with existing players. After a cost and benefit analysis they need to consider that privacy concerns need to be addressed (especially since the PDP law is not in force) and commitments need to be mandated for potential dominance issues," Sanghi said. Agreeing with the sentiment, Aneja said that the competition policy needed to be updated to take into consideration control over data and network effects. "Competition policy normally looks at impact on customers in terms of price. But that's not enough in case of zero price/ two-sided marketplace. It needs to also evaluate the impact of controlling customer data, network effects, and effect of M&A on the competitiveness of the market," she said.Jain says regulatory bodies need to take vigil towards privacy and data misuse."I think Privacy is one of the key areas for regulatory bodies to dive into. Establishing clear guardrails around privacy is very important and will only get more important. This is especially important with respect to Google and Facebook. Though Amazon is the dominant e-commerce platform by far (38% market share vs. 6% for #2 Walmart), it is still less than 6% of all US retail sales). That being said, regulatory bodies in the US will eventually have to look at anti-competitive practices because of the massive dominance Amazon has in e-commerce."Comparing Jio with the big tech, Jain said these giants have their hands in everything from streaming to video chat to e-commerce. "They have brand loyalty, a soaring stock price and are intensely competitive, though, perhaps not very innovative with tech products. All big tech companies have shown similar characteristics without controlling the pipes. I think Jio could eventually be the gateway to the Internet in India." For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

urn:contentItem:5RWB-VS61-JCMN-Y054-00000-00As a smart-home war with Amazon looms, Nest releases its first new products since rejoining Google (AMZN, GOOG, GOOGL)2018-03-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:38ZLexisNexisAs a smart-home war with Amazon looms, Nest releases its first new products since rejoining Google (AMZN, GOOG, GOOGL)Matt Weinberger

Mar 15, 2018( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Nest announced the availability of the $229 Nest Hello video doorbell and the $249 Nest x Yale smart lock, as well as a remote temperature sensor for the Nest Learning Thermostat. The new Nest products launch just weeks after Amazon announced it had purchased video doorbell maker Ring for about $1 billion. Amazon also will no longer sell devices from Nest. Nest itself was recently reabsorbed into Google.

While a smart-home war with Amazon is definitely on the horizon, Nest tells Business Insider that it's committed to openness and cross-device compatibility, and hopes Amazon feels the same way.A smart-home war between Amazon and Google is brewing. Just weeks after Google announced that it would reabsorb Nest[1]after years of independent operation, Amazon snatched up video doorbell maker Ring for a reported $1 billion[2]. And that's not to mention the fact that Amazon won't be selling any of Nest's products.[3] Now, Nest is gearing up to fire back: On Thursday, Nest announced that the previously-announced Nest Hello video doorbell ($229) and Nest x Yale smart door lock ($249) are now both available for sale — plus, a $39 temperature sensor for the company's flagship Nest Learning Thermostat. The products themselves play into the combined Google-Nest ecosystem. For instance, if you use the Nest app to open the new Nest x Yale lock, it can automatically disarm the Nest Secure home security system[4]. Or, you can use the Google Home smart speaker to cue up the Nest Hello doorbell video feed to play on a TV with a Google Chromecast. Indeed, a recent software update turns the Nest Cam IQ Indoor camera into a Google Assistant-powered smart speaker — with the limitation that it can't play music, only answer questions and control other smart-home gear.It's that ecosystem, as well as its Google-powered artificial intelligence, that Nest sees as making all the difference, says Maxime Veron, Nest's director of product marketing, a 6-year veteran of the company. "We don't expect consumers to buy it all at once," says Veron. But every Nest or Google device you buy makes all of the other ones better, he says. And with today's news, Nest now offers everything from cameras to door locks to security systems to thermostats and smoke detectors — a breadth unmatched by most competitors, let alone Amazon, he says. On the subject of Amazon, Veron calls the company's purchase of Ring "interesting," with many details left to be revealed — including whether Amazon plans to maintain Ring's current compatibility with the Google Assistant platform. For its part, though, Nest prides itself on playing nicely with others, says Veron. You can use an app for the Google Home speaker to control a Ring camera, and you can use an Amazon Echo app to control the Nest thermostat. Veron doesn't see any reason for that to change, no matter what the relationship between the two companies is like. "Nest is very open to openness," says Veron. "We have no plan to disrupt that at this point." He likens it to how Nest maintains an app for both iPhone and Android. If a customer wants to use an Amazon Echo to control their Nest gadgetry, that's their choice. He does say, however, that Google Assistant is Nest's "platform of choice right now." Still, now that the company has been reabsorbed into Google after years as an Alphabet subsidiary, there are some questions that Nest will have to answer for itself. For instance: For the last several years, Nest has been cultivating a "Works With Nest" smart-home ecosystem of products that all integrate with one another. However, Google has its own, fast-growing — but separate — ecosystem around Google Assistant. Even Nest isn't yet clear if there's any point in keeping both going. "Is it best for a company to have two different initiatives, or just one?" asks Veron. He says that it's still something they're thinking about. Similarly, there hasn't been a decision over whether Nest will maintain a separate smartphone app, or just integrate directly into the Google Home app, where Google Assistant users control their home devices. Ultimately, though, Veron believes that Nest and Google will benefit from the reunification. Google brings facial recognition and other artificial-intelligence smarts to the table; Nest has extensive experience in building devices and providing services. Together, he says, they can step up the integrations of their products, and go beyond. "We're actually talking now about how to benefit from each other's strengths," says Veron. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S6T-8VK1-F0J6-J3WD-00000-00As Australia reels over revela...2018-04-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:38ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 38As Australia reels over revela...John McDuling

As Australia reels over revelations of rampant misconduct in its financial services sector, the United States is coming to grips with the scary dominance of its tech giants.

After a troubling few months, particularly for Facebook, it seems a matter of if, not when, the iconic tech companies that increasingly dominate the US stockmarket, and modern life, will face more onerous regulation than they enjoy now.

"We are in uncharted territory today, with companies doing hundreds of billions of dollars in revenue and still growing at rates of 20-25 per cent," Goldman Sachs analysts said in a lengthy tome on this very topic last week.

"Regulators have never had to deal with something like this before - and it's happening at a much faster rate than they are used to."

In recent weeks, US President Donald Trump has repeatedly taken aim at Amazon, probably because its CEO and founder Jeff Bezos personally owns The Washington Post - which has broken a string of stories damaging to him.

Trump has accused the e-commerce firm of dodging taxes and ripping off the publicly funded postal service, ordering an investigation into the latter.

"I am right about Amazon costing the United States Post Office massive amounts of money for being their Delivery Boy. Amazon should pay these costs (plus) and not have them bourne by the American Taxpayer. Many billions of dollars. P.O. leaders don't have a clue (or do they?)!" - Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) April 3, 2018.

Meanwhile, the Supreme Court (which is entirely independent of Trump, yet currently dominated by conservative leaning judges) is considering whether to hear a case that could see state sales taxes imposed on Amazon and other e-commerce companies.

Facebook has incurred the wrath of legislators (CEO Mark Zuckerberg was recently hauled before Congress) after it emerged that data of millions of users had been harvested by Cambridge Analytica, a political consultancy that worked for the Trump campaign in 2016.

The social media behemoth is also being investigated by the Federal Trade Commission, a key competition agency, over this episode.

Google's YouTube business last year was hit by an advertiser backlash after it failed to deal with hate speech and extremist content. Even Apple has not been immune from the backlash after some of its own investors called on it to do more to stop smartphone addiction.

As I have written previously, the tech sector, which not long ago enjoyed broad bipartisan support in its home market, is suddenly looking politically isolated in the US.

Republicans don't trust it - most people who work in tech are ultra-progressive on social issues, and Democrats have been turned off by the industry's growing stranglehold over vast swaths of the economy, and the questionable practices of some of its participants.

Despite this changing political climate, Congress is still plagued by paralysis - it's doubtful whether it can get anything done. As a result, it may fall to institutions removed from the short-term political process, such as the FTC or the Supreme Court, to act.

In Europe, the climate for big American tech companies is even frostier. Competition laws in Europe are different to America's - they are less narrowly focused on impacts to prices paid by consumers, and unlike the US don't assume that markets ultimately work.

Google last year was hit with a record (EURO)2.4 billion fine by European competition regulators for (trivial sounding) breaches of rules relating to online shopping ads. The stakes are much higher now.

Europe is also being much more aggressive on regulating privacy issues. The EU's GDPR (General Data Production Regulation) regime comes into effect next month. It will affect any industry that collects data on its customers.

For the the likes of Google and Facebook it will require users to "opt-in" to allow their data be used for various purposes. Under a worst case scenario, Goldman estimates that Google's advertising revenue could be hit by 2 per cent, and Facebook's by as much as 7 per cent, due to GDPR.

Notably, other analysts have argued that GDPR could actually benefit the tech giants, as complying with it will prove burdensome for many smaller companies.

For instance, Credit Suisse has described GDPR as an "unambiguous positive for operators such as Facebook", arguing it has a higher likelihood of receiving approval from users than other internet firms that might interact with customers less frequently.

Anyone with a rudimentary grasp of recent business history will recognise the significance of Wall Street firms increasingly fixating on the question of regulating big tech.

Goldman, famously described by Rolling Stone as a "great vampire squid wrapped around the face of humanity", was itself the centre of consumer anger, and regulatory scrutiny, only a short while ago.

It's barely a decade since Wall Street plunged the world's biggest economy (and the world economy) into the worst recession since the Great Depression of the 1920s.

Australia, through a combination of luck and skill, dodged the worst of that crisis. As a result, our financial institutions didn't suffer the kind of backlash they are only just beginning to witness now as a result of the scandals exposed by the royal commission.

America's biggest financial firms, Goldman included, know all too well what a populist backlash, and ensuing regulation, looks and feels like. It's something the country's tech sector will be desperate to avoid.

In Europe the climate for the US companies is even frostier.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VGG-NN01-JCRW-530B-00000-00As BB&T-SunTrust shows, banks must grow, change or die2019-02-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:39ZLexisNexisAs BB&T-SunTrust shows, banks must grow, change or dieKaren Shaw Petrou

The BB&T-SunTrust merger is drawingstrong oppositionon grounds that so large a merger means still more banking sector concentration. It's true that big banks have gotten bigger since 2008 even as the community bank landscape is increasingly decimated.

It's time, though, to shift the debate from whether big banks should be allowed to merge to even more urgent questions. If banks don't merge, then what? Does the U.S. want a banking system made up largely of a few giant banks and a few even larger monolithic big tech companies? If not, then banks must grow in size and/or change their offerings if Congress does not apply like-kind regulation to increasingly powerful competitors operating often within the ambit of taxpayer backstops while enjoying immunity from costly regulation.

How powerful is the threat from outside the battle lines defined by bank-on-bank competition? According to the head of the Bank for International Settlements, banks face an"existential threat"from global big-tech companies with market capitalization now exceeding that of the global financial sector. Even so, the latestbig tech report from the Financial Stability Boardshows that all global regulators can think of to do is watch unsure of what to do as finance quickly migrates outside their reach. BB&T and SunTrust understandably bet on the likelihood that Congress will stand by as U.S. finance changes under the onslaught of empowered nonbanks and big techs. They thus decided to redefine themselves before the market did it for them.

Yet instead of recognizing the threat from outside of the banking industry, the BB&T-SunTrust merger battle is shaping up along lines first marked out in the 1970s, as regional banks began to consolidate among themselves and with what were then called money-center banks. Battles then over interstate banking may strike us now as quaint - akin to battles over allowing automobiles on city streets at the turn of the 20th century - but strong forces opposed interstate branching and slowed it down for at least a decade. It took until 1994 before interstate branching was fully legal, but many banks by then had redefined the merger landscape by finding ways to expand no matter the seeming legal impediments.

When customers increasingly worked in one state and commuted home into another and began to travel farther afield, banks that couldn't follow were banks that couldn't survive. Growth then was made essential by profound technology and market changes. The U.S. financial marketplace is of course no more immune to these forces in 2019 than it was 40 years ago. In 1979, the big challenges were fast-changing telecommunications and computing technology combined with an anachronistic regulatory framework that imposed deposit interest rate ceilings despite rampant inflation and adroit nonbank competition. In 2019, we've got a new round of paradigm-busting telecommunications and technology changes, a tough regulatory system governing only some financial service providers, and - yet again - little constraint on mixing banking and commerce, as long as "banking" is banking in all but regulated name.

This competitive landscape isn't pretty, but it's all too real. To their credit, BB&T and SunTrust put aside the parochial questions of which CEO takes charge to craft what could well be among the very few true mergers of equals. The deal adds sufficient economies of scale to ensure efficiencies of scope and a future as a regulated bank - at least for a while longer.

The merits of this merger are for the Federal Reserve and then the market to judge. What is clear is that the financial market of 2019 will find a way to innovate even if regulated banks are hamstrung from doing so. Forty years ago, banks exploited regulatory loopholes to cross borders and serve their customers. In 2019, banks will redefine their businesses within the tougher boundaries of banking law to make profits where they can. Many are thus shifting from traditional consumer banking offerings to a strong focus on wealth management. This is a perverse consequence of all the post-crisis rules with a pernicious economic equality impact, but it's evident across the array of retail finance offerings emanating from the regulated sector.

Who will serve the rest of the market? I suspect low- and moderate-income households will find it still harder to get essential financial services on equitable, affordable terms. Nonbank and big tech providers are cherry-picking the value chain of financial products to select the deposit, loan and payment offerings that profit them the most - and why not?

Nonbank, fintech and big tech companies are doing what competitors do when the wind is at their backs.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VGC-N5P1-F06X-W0J1-00000-00As BB&T-SunTrust shows, banks must grow, change or die2019-02-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:39ZLexisNexisAs BB&T-SunTrust shows, banks must grow, change or dieKaren Shaw Petrou

The BB&T-SunTrust merger is drawingstrong oppositionon grounds that so large a merger means still more banking sector concentration. It's true that big banks have gotten bigger since 2008 even as the community bank landscape is increasingly decimated.

It's time, though, to shift the debate from whether big banks should be allowed to merge to even more urgent questions. If banks don't merge, then what? Does the U.S. want a banking system made up largely of a few giant banks and a few even larger monolithic big tech companies? If not, then banks must grow in size and/or change their offerings if Congress does not apply like-kind regulation to increasingly powerful competitors operating often within the ambit of taxpayer backstops while enjoying immunity from costly regulation.

How powerful is the threat from outside the battle lines defined by bank-on-bank competition? According to the head of the Bank for International Settlements, banks face an"existential threat"from global big-tech companies with market capitalization now exceeding that of the global financial sector. Even so, the latestbig tech report from the Financial Stability Boardshows that all global regulators can think of to do is watch unsure of what to do as finance quickly migrates outside their reach. BB&T and SunTrust understandably bet on the likelihood that Congress will stand by as U.S. finance changes under the onslaught of empowered nonbanks and big techs. They thus decided to redefine themselves before the market did it for them.

Yet instead of recognizing the threat from outside of the banking industry, the BB&T-SunTrust merger battle is shaping up along lines first marked out in the 1970s, as regional banks began to consolidate among themselves and with what were then called money-center banks. Battles then over interstate banking may strike us now as quaint - akin to battles over allowing automobiles on city streets at the turn of the 20th century - but strong forces opposed interstate branching and slowed it down for at least a decade. It took until 1994 before interstate branching was fully legal, but many banks by then had redefined the merger landscape by finding ways to expand no matter the seeming legal impediments.

When customers increasingly worked in one state and commuted home into another and began to travel farther afield, banks that couldn't follow were banks that couldn't survive. Growth then was made essential by profound technology and market changes. The U.S. financial marketplace is of course no more immune to these forces in 2019 than it was 40 years ago. In 1979, the big challenges were fast-changing telecommunications and computing technology combined with an anachronistic regulatory framework that imposed deposit interest rate ceilings despite rampant inflation and adroit nonbank competition. In 2019, we've got a new round of paradigm-busting telecommunications and technology changes, a tough regulatory system governing only some financial service providers, and - yet again - little constraint on mixing banking and commerce, as long as "banking" is banking in all but regulated name.

This competitive landscape isn't pretty, but it's all too real. To their credit, BB&T and SunTrust put aside the parochial questions of which CEO takes charge to craft what could well be among the very few true mergers of equals. The deal adds sufficient economies of scale to ensure efficiencies of scope and a future as a regulated bank - at least for a while longer.

The merits of this merger are for the Federal Reserve and then the market to judge. What is clear is that the financial market of 2019 will find a way to innovate even if regulated banks are hamstrung from doing so. Forty years ago, banks exploited regulatory loopholes to cross borders and serve their customers. In 2019, banks will redefine their businesses within the tougher boundaries of banking law to make profits where they can. Many are thus shifting from traditional consumer banking offerings to a strong focus on wealth management. This is a perverse consequence of all the post-crisis rules with a pernicious economic equality impact, but it's evident across the array of retail finance offerings emanating from the regulated sector.

Who will serve the rest of the market? I suspect low- and moderate-income households will find it still harder to get essential financial services on equitable, affordable terms. Nonbank and big tech providers are cherry-picking the value chain of financial products to select the deposit, loan and payment offerings that profit them the most - and why not?

Nonbank, fintech and big tech companies are doing what competitors do when the wind is at their backs.
